entry.title: ISSEI Restaurant / Studio Kota
entry.summary: Located in the heart of Jakarta‚Äôs Central Business District Issei is a casual Japanese restaurant by day and sake bar by night. The design is inspired by organic pattern of natural landscape. This idea is translated into free flow curvatures that are applied into the geometry of the seatings and hanging screens. The main dining area is characterized by its double height ceiling space filled with large curvy hanging screens. These semi transparent screens are coordinated with the geometry of the seating layo‚Ä¶

entry.summary: Posted by Nachiappan Valliappan, Senior Software Engineer and Kai Kohlhoff, Staff Research Scientist, Google Research Eye movement has been studied widely across vision science, language, and usability since the 1970s. entry.title: Vacation Inbox ‚Äî All your vacation research and ideas in one place
entry.summary:
“ Hi Product Hunt,
I'm Isaac founder of Vacation Inbox.
Did you know most people on average spend over 20 hours planning to go on vacations?
We at Vacation Inbox found that there was no good tool out there to consolidate all the planning and have it organized for travel. Some common answers we found people are using to plan their trips are gmail, Facebook Messenger, Slack, Trello, Evernote and even pen and paper.

entry.summary:
“ Hi everyone at ProductHunt
I want to present you my latest app: Duplica.
With Duplica you can share your iPhone and iPad screen on a web browser remotely without limitations around the world, all you need is just an internet connection.
Because Duplica uses a web browser, you can mirror the iOs screen in almost any other device, both desktop (Mac, Windows or Linux) and mobile (iPad, iPhone or Android devices), and it supports the sharing to a Chromecast also.

entry.title: Flagsmith ‚Äî Feature flag, remote config and AB testing platform
entry.summary:
“ Hey hunters!
Flagsmith was born as a side project of the dev agency I was running in London for the last 20 years. We saw how valuable feature flagging could be to improve product velocity for our clients, but couldn't find a good open source platform to work from, so we started Flagsmith!
We open sourced the project a couple of years ago and have added both SaaS and Enteprise/On Prem offerings since then.
I'd love to hear people's feedback! ”

entry.title: Markdown for Microsoft Word ‚Äî Work with markdown in Microsoft Word. In app and online
entry.summary:
“ I often write texts in Word. In particular I work with Markdown markup.
Previously I had to use other text editors because Word could not show Markdown preview. But I really like Word because its proofing features, cloud syncing, collaborative editing and more.
That's why I decided to create this add-in. Now it's possible to work in habitat editor and get Markdown preview in the same place without any trade-offs.
Please let me know what you think üòâ ”

entry.title: Webtor ‚Äî Download and play torrents with free cloud BitTorrent client
entry.summary:
“ Hi! I am happy to present Webtor here.
Just want to list some additional things that you can do with Webtor: 1. Download whole torrent as ZIP-archive. 2. Transcode torrent content on-the-fly (supports MKV, AVI and so on). 3. Automatically attach subtitles from OpenSubtitles.org. 4. Place webtor player on your website.
By the way, most of Webtor's backend components are opensourced under MIT license. You can find code on github https://github.com/webtor-io
Enjoy! ”

entry.title: (OBG) Don't Confuse Levels of Representation Part 2

entry.title: Tail Latency Might Matter More Than You Think
entry.summary: Tail Latency Might Matter More Than You Think A frustratingly qualitative approach. Tail latency, also known as high-percentile latency, refers to high latencies that clients see fairly infrequently. Things like: "my service mostly responds in around 10ms, but sometimes takes around 100ms". There are many causes of tail latency in the world, including contention, garbage collection, packet loss, host failure, and weird stuff operating systems do in the background. entry.title: Optimizing `string::append` is harder than it looks
entry.summary: Back in early March, Lukas B√∂ger asked on StackOverflow: ‚ÄúWhere do standard library or compilers leverage noexcept move semantics (other than vector growth)?‚Äù So I got nerdsniped into looking at all the places libc++ tests the noexceptness of any user-defined operation. This circuitously led to my finding an absolutely massive number of corner-case bugs in libc++‚Äôs string::append member function. In hindsight, it was a mistake for C++ to use the same keyword for ‚Äúmaking a function (conditionally) noexcept‚Äù ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How I Implemented /dev/printerfact in Rust
entry.summary:
How I Implemented /dev/printerfact in Rust Kernel mode programming is a frightful endeavor. One of the big problems with it is that C is really your only option on Linux. C has many historical problems with it that can't really be fixed at this point without radically changing the language to the point that existing code written in C would be incompatible with it. DISCLAIMER: This is pre-alpha stuff. I expect this post to bitrot quickly. **DO NOT EXPECT THIS TO STILL WORK IN A FEW YEARS.**

entry.title: Redundant against what?
entry.summary: Redundant against what? Threat modeling thinking to distributed systems. There's basically one fundamental reason that distributed systems can achieve better availability than single-box systems: redundancy. The software, state, and other things needed to run a system are present in multiple places. When one of those places fails, the others can take over. This applies to replicated databases, load-balanced stateless systems, serverless systems, and almost all other common distributed patterns. One problem ‚Ä¶
